data.text: Most of my trips are type 2 fun. Well thought out, usually gear that accommodate the conditions, best of intentions, usually bite off more than I can chew or the weather turns on me. Can be miserable in the moment but I always have great stories and I'm always thankful for the experience when I'm done. During a trip - I always take opportunities to improvise routes, kill some time when I find interesting or beautiful things, or cut a day short because I find a place too perfect to camp and end up having 50% more riding to do the next day. Coddiwomple - to travel in a purposeful manner towards a vague destination.

data.text: We lean towards winging it. Sometimes bad weather hits, and you can't put in the number of miles you expected. Or any other many issues that could cause you to go shorter or longer than expected. So we almost always book hotels as we go, calling maybe halfway through the day to lock something in, or sometimes just showing up and booking on the spot. One challenge with that is if you are in a busy, popular area, hotels could be booked. And in very remote areas, you might only have one lodging choice. So it could pay in some places to lock in your lodging. As for the route, we usually adhere to it, but occasionally in the middle of a trip, we'll tweak our route a bit. Again, leaning towards winging it more than planning every last detail.

The lodge was open, but wouldn‚Äôt sell us food due to limited staffing. We ate our reserve dehydrated meals that night. I work as a commercial construction manager, and therefore believe if you fail to plan, plan to fail. data.text: I bicycle tour to relax, collect experience, and to enjoy life in the way that brings joy to me üôÇ We are all different, enjoy different ways of doing things - and have different requirements when it comes to the need of knowing what is ahead. I like to read and study history when prepearing for a trip - being prepeard to meet people, understand some if the culture, and make better choices on route. Actual ¬´planning¬ª is kept to a minimum. The freedom that going with no set distance or route give let me realx, enjoy - and just be. As an example, I cycled coast-to-coast in the US (New York to Los Angeles via Canada and Mexico) at 14 days notice. I cycled the whole distance ¬´alone¬ª with my 8 kids (aged 12 months to 17 years old). The ¬´planning¬ª was limited to arranging formalities around home schooling (for 5 kids), visas, and air tickets (to New York and return tickets from LA 9 months later). The rest, including route, we just ¬´winged it¬ª as we cycled. We had an amazing experience, and cycled the while trio without a map. Wild camping most if the nights, pickng durections based on the sun, prepearing shopping and distances based on the road signes. This is one way to travel, but not the only one. Sometimes you need to plan a bit to be safe (remote areas, terrain, weather/temperature) or due to technicallities (visas, border crossings, ferries, air travel) - and ofcourse, the more time constrained you are, the more planning is needed.
